description: The Fliegerfaust, or 'air fist' was a prototype unguided anti-air weapon that was designed to be portable to the common infantryman in the latter days of the Third Reich. This particular model is the Fliegerfaust B, and boasts of nine barrels to fire small 20mm unguided rockets.
A simple framework designed to mount nine fliegerfaust rockets within the fliegerfaust B.

The M-28 or M-29 Davy Crockett Weapon System is a tactical nuclear recoilless smoothbore gun for firing the M388 nuclear projectile, armed with the W54 nuclear warhead, that was deployed by the United States during the Cold War. It is most widely renknowned for using the smallest nuclear weapon ever made, although also is infamous for its rather poor accuracy.

Developed by the obscure New Zealander Engineer, Russ Robinson, the SR.R Model 14 is a shoulder fired variant of the M2 browning developed during the hectic and desperate days that Australia saw in the early years of the second world war. It is essentially a version of the famed M2 browning that was simplified and ligthened enough to be (rather uncomfortably) fired from a standing shoulder position.

First manufactured at the end of the Second World War, the M18 Recoilless Rifle is an American general purpose anti-tank weapon that saw service throughout the early days of the cold war in conflict zones all over the globe. Unlike its rocket-propelled predecessors, the M18 uses a recoilless rifle system, combining the power of an anti-tank rocket system with the more conventional ballistics of rifled weapons. Although intended for use as part of a two-man crew, the M18 can also be used by a single man in times of emergency expediency.

A disposable light anti-tank weapon fielded by Nazi Germany during the second world war. A common misconception is that it's a rocket, when it's actually a recoilless rifle. Feared by many an allied tank crew (and the volksturm who had to use them without training).
//: A tube with a lever.  Unsurprisingly, dirt cheap (at least for a rocket launcher).

description: A mortar designed to be used at the squad level, the Type 89 grenade discharger was one of the Japanese Empire's most unique weapons employed during the later days of its rule across Asia. A derivative of the earlier Type 10 grenade discharger with the inclusion of rifling, the Type 89 was capable of using a variety of ammunition loads, including the ubiquitous Type 91 grenade. Although little more than a rifled tube, baseplate and striker, the Type 89 became a feared weapon in the pacific, perhaps in small part from unwitting marines breaking their femurs due to the mortar's peculiar moniker.

A large flamethrower designed for the US military on the eve of its entry into the Second World War, saw a great deal of combat in the pacific theater.  Very menacing and deadly, especially to Japanese pacific island garrisons.
A 4L pressurized steel canister with a valve designed for the RM451's feed system.
